thread.section_title: Archive News & Video for Thursday, 19 Apr 2018 | Reuters.com
thread.title: WEEKAHEAD-AFRICA-FX-Demand for dollars likely to weigh on Kenyan shilling

author: Reuters Editorial
title: WEEKAHEAD-AFRICA-FX-Demand for dollars likely to weigh on Kenyan shilling
text:
NAIROBI, April 19 (Reuters) - Demand for dollars by importers looking to lock in favourable rates after the Kenyan shilling’s recent gains are likely to weigh on the currency while the Nigerian naira is expected to be stable.
KENYA Kenya’s currency could come under pressure from the dollar in the coming week from importers seeking to take advantage of the shilling’s recent strengthening.
At 0800 GMT, commercial banks Quote: d the shilling at 100.40/50 compared with 100.60/70 at last Thursday’s close.
“We are likely to see more import orders from merchants taking advantage of the price, progressively weakening the shilling bit by bit,” said a trader from a commercial bank.
NIGERIA The Nigerian naira is likely to remain stable in the week ahead, boosted by the central bank’s ability to intervene on the currency market amid rising foreign exchange reserves and higher crude prices, traders said.
Hard currency reserves rose to $47 billion as of April 16, providing more ammunition to defend the naira. The country runs a two-year-old multiple foreign exchange system, which has been criticized by the International Monetary Fund.
On the official market, the naira was Quote: d at around 305.60 while importers bid for dollars from the central bank at 337 naira. The local currency traded at around 360 per dollar for investors.
ZAMBIA The Zambian kwacha is likely to hold firm next week supported by hard currency sales from companies preparing to pay taxes and other month-end obligations.
At 1115 GMT, commercial banks Quote: d the currency of Africa’s No.2 copper producer at 9.4600 per dollar, stronger than a close of 9.5000 last Thursday.
“It should hold the latest gains as we approach the end of the month when dollar supply increases,” one commercial bank trader said, referring to the kwacha.
UGANDA The Ugandan shilling is expected to weaken over the next few days, hurt by projected higher demand for dollars from importers.
At 0948 GMT, commercial banks Quote: d the shilling at 3,690/3,700, unchanged from last Thursday’s closing rate.
The market anticipated demand from importers of retail goods in the coming days to replenish stocks for next month which they “expect to push the shilling to post some losses,” said a trader from a commercial bank.
The shilling was likely to trade in the 3,695/3,705 range over the next one week, he said.
TANZANIA The Tanzanian shilling could remain under pressure in the days ahead due to surging dollar demand from oil, manufacturing and construction sectors amid subdued inflows of the U.S. currency, analysts said.
Commercial banks Quote: d the shilling at 2,278/2,288 to the dollar on Thursday, weaker than 2,262/2,267 a week ago.
“We expect the shilling to remain under pressure next week because of a shortage of foreign currency in the market, largely because tourism and agricultural exports are in the off season,” said a trader at CRDB Bank. (Reporting by Chijikoe Ohuocha, John Ndiso, Elias Biryabarema, Fumbuka Ng’wanakilala and Chris Mfula Editing by Duncan Miriri and Andrew Heavens)
